If it is a thing that mortals know, the DM should know it. For instance, the example of how the villain's henchmen are doing something--the DM should know because the party might drop everything to go figure it out.
However, if it's information that is unknown to mortal actors--for instance, precisely how the ancient empire forged its steel to be so hard, a method lost to modern civilizations--you don't need to know it. That can be a mystery, as can the true nature of the gods.
Put simply, anything that a living NPC knows, you need to know, too. Anything else, you just need to establish the rules of consistency that you're going to follow so that you don't contradict yourself.

threads.sub: Selling the power and prestige of mid/high-level, mortal humanoid grunts
threads.com:
It is something I have seen in countless published adventures across D&D 3.5, D&D 4e, D&D 5e, Pathfinder 1e, Pathfinder 2e, and even 13th Age.

The characters are mid/high-level. The PCs are capable of fighting adult dragons, greater demons and devils, rakshasa sorcerers, beholders, and even stronger threats. And yet, the adventure author decides to write in one or more challenging encounters against a small group of nameless, mortal humanoid grunts with no buildup. A small group, not some massive army. (Pathfinder 2e's Agents of Edgewatch #5 has over twenty CR 12 street gang thugs across the adventure. 13th Age's Games of Power is a mini-adventure for max-level PCs, who can slay ancient dragons and balors; the first challenging encounter is against a rebellious noble house's guards, including some mooks who are explicitly supposed to be "in training.")

Why? Who knows. For some reason, adventure authors sometimes forget that mid/high-level PCs are essentially superheroes, and that it becomes increasingly implausible for them to be seriously threatened by a group of <20 mundane, mortal humanoid grunts with no buildup. For some reason, adventure authors want to tell a low-level story with low-level obstacles even though the PCs are much stronger.

But it is not just published adventures. Actual GMs do this, too. I have been playing tabletop games for a long time. I have frequently seen GMs field mid/high-level, mortal humanoid grunts as opponents with no buildup. Hours ago, I played a mid-level session of Eberron in Pathfinder 2e; this is a setting with extremely reduced NPC power levels, and yet the party was being challenged by common crooks who were performing a heist, with no buildup of importance or prestige.

How do you make this more plausible? Do you use the idea of enemy special forces renowned for their puissance? "You are facing the legendary champions of the [Redcloak Battalion/Black Cadre/Blackamber Legion/Ebon Gauntlet]. These are no ordinary soldiers."

Ritual Magic fits TES/Morrowind pretty well, so I'd just tweak that rather than use a different starting point.

I think your best bet is to just remove the default between College skills and your Core skill; if you want to cast fire spells for example, you need to put at least one point into College of Fire instead of just pumping more and more points into Ritual Magic and riding that default. This approach both helps the balance out by not letting every mage cast literally any spell off of a single skill *and* it fits the Morrowind skills system where you level magic schools completely independently of each other much more closely IMO.

That being said, removing the default may be overly punishing, since there are over 20 different colleges and all are IQ/VH. You might want to consider retooling the colleges, combining them into a smaller list of broader colleges. This has the added benefit of also aping Morrowind's schools of magic. I don't think you could do an easy grouping of colleges as-is due to many colleges providing a wide variety of spell effects (like GURPS's Illusion & Creation school needing to be broken up between Morrowind's School of Illusion and School of Conjuration, or GURPS's Necromantic college having spells that could go to Conjuration, Mysticism, Alteration, and Destruction), so sadly this requires a good deal of elbow grease on your part. Or you just provide guidelines and accept that you'll need to do some mid-game adjudication when a player asks if a given spell falls into a school or not; instead of having to do a ton of work before the game starts, you do a tiny bit of work only right when you need it.
